Description: A pottery flask modelled in the form of a bird, perhaps a dove. The vessel has a waisted neck flaring to a plain rim, flanked by applied handles, rising from the back of the bird. The beak is pierced for pouring. The bird stands on a flaring foot, hollow within and now damaged. The object was put together from four, probably five, wheel-made elements and two handles: the body was thrown as a pot with a flaring mouth, the mouth was flattened and pressed together to form the tail, and the breast was fashioned by roughly rounding off the bottom of the pot; the mouth was thrown and applied to the back of the bird, in which a hole had been cut, and two substantial handles were added between the mouth and the flanks of the body; the neck of the bird was thrown and added, again with a hole cut through the body; the face and beak were hand-modelled or, more probably thrown, and applied to the neck. The beak was pierced; the base was thrown and luted to the underside of the body. Buff marl ware, possibly Abu Mena Buff Ware; decorated in brown fired-on ceramic colour: the eyes and a stripe down the head and beak; a collar with a decorative pendant; scrolls on the breast and shoulders; crossed 'arrows' and scrolls on the tail.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Purchased: Greville J. Chester. Late Roman, about fifth to seventh century AD. Bibliog: Glanville 1926: pl. xiv:5.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3776)
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Rev Greville John Chester
